metadata.title: New insights on the influence of organic co-contaminants on the aquatic toxicology of carbon nanomaterials

Article
New insights on the influence of organic co-contaminants on the aquatic toxicology of carbon nanomaterials
Josep Sanchís, Mar Olmos, Phil Vincent, Marinella Farré, and Damia Barcelo Environ. Sci. Technol., Just Accepted Manuscript • DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b03966 • Publication Date (Web): 22 Dec 2015
Downloaded from http://pubs.acs.org on December 27, 2015

New insights on the influence of organic co-contaminants on the 1
aquatic toxicology of carbon nanomaterials 2
3
Josep Sanchís 1 , Mar Olmos 1 , Phil Vincent 2 , Marinella Farré 1* , Damià Barceló 1,3 4 5 6 1 Institute of Environmental Assessment and Water Research (IDAEA-CSIC), C/Jordi 7 Girona, 18-26, 08911, Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. 8 2 NanoSight Ltd., Minton Park, London Road, Amesbury, Wiltshire SP4 7RT, United 9
Kingdom 10 3 Catalan Institute of Water Research (ICRA), C/ Emili Grahit, 101, 17003, Girona, 11 Catalonia,Spain. 12 13
*Corresponding author: Marinella Farré. 14
Address: C/Jordi Girona, 18-26, 08034 Barcelona 15 Phone: 0034 934 006 100 16 Fax: 0034 932 045 904 17 18
Page 2 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
ABSTRACT 19 At present, there is a lack of understanding on the combined ecotoxicity of carbon-20 based nanomaterials and co-contaminants. In this paper, we report on the toxicity of 21
three carbon nanomaterials (fullerene-soot, multiwall carbon nanotubes and 22 graphene). 23 Two standardized toxicity bioassays, the immobilization of the invertebrate Daphnia 24 magna and the bioluminescence inhibition of the marine bacteria Vibrio fischeri, have 25 been used. Synergistic and antagonistic effects of binary mixtures composed of 26 fullerene soot and organic co-contaminants as malathion, glyphosate, diuron, triclosan, 27 and nonylphenol were assessed. The isobologram method was used to evaluate the 28 concentrations producing an effect, in comparison to those effects expected by a simple 29 additive approach. In this study, antagonism was the predominant effect. However, 30 synergism was also observed as in the case of D. magna exposed to mixtures of 31 malathion and fullerene soot. D. magna was shown to be the most sensitive assay when 32 carbon nanomaterials were present. Toxicity to D. magna was as follows: fullerene soot 33 > multi-wall carbon nanotubes > graphene. These results were proportional to the size 34 of aggregates, smaller aggregates being the most toxic. The vector function of 35 nanomaterials aggregates and the unexpected release inside living organisms was 36 proved for malathion. 37 These results highlight new insights on the risks associated with the release of carbon 38 nanomaterials into the environment. 39 40 Keywords Nanomaterials, fullerenes, carbon nanotubes, toxicity, Trojan horse effect, 41 synergism, antagonisms, organic contaminants. 42 43
Page 3 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
Introduction 44 The production and use of the different groups of nanomaterials (NMs) is expected to 45 increase during the coming years (1). Carbon NMs such as fullerenes, multiwall carbon 46 nanotubes (MWCNTs) and graphene nanoflakes are currently applied in electronics (2, 47 3), as potential drug carriers (4), in analytical chemistry (5), and are the basis of new 48 materials (6). Moreover, carbon NMs are also emitted from combustion sources (7). 49 However, the same physical properties based on their large surface-to-volume ratio that 50 have made the nanotechnological success are also the basis of their potential risk for the 51 environment and living organisms (8, 9). Thus, NMs are currently considered as 52 emerging pollutants (10). 53 The fate, behavior and potential risks of the increasing presence of NMs in the 54 environment, continue to be poorly understood (11). The importance of understanding 55 the chemistry of NMs in the context of ecotoxicity and bioavailability should be 56 stressed. The size (12), shape (13), surface area (14), their diffusion capacity, 57 aggregation/agglomeration properties in suspension (11, 15), functionalization and the 58 possible interaction with other contaminants must be considered to assess their 59 ecotoxicological risk. Besides, in aquatic ecosystems, their uptake from the water 60 column by primary producer organisms and their possible transfer to food chains should 61 be assessed. Moreover, carbon NMs are sorptive materials and may play a significant 62 role in the partition, transport and toxicity of other contaminants in a similar manner to 63 the effect of black carbon, suspended particulate matter and colloids in river water, 64 which have been studied for decades (16-19). However, NMs show extreme surface-to-65 volume ratios and dynamic aggregation/agglomeration behaviors, which justify their 66 study. Currently, the role of carbon NMs as vectors for other contaminants is an almost 67 overlooked aspect, and few studies have been carried out. For example, Baun et al. (20) 68 studied the influence of C60 fullerene aggregates on the aquatic toxicity of other 69 contaminants. Baun et al., found that the toxicity of pentachlorophenol, phenanthrene 70 was changed while, for other contaminants such as atrazine and methyl parathion, the 71 toxicity remained unchanged. Also in other examples, the toxicity of diuron to 72 Chlorella vulgaris was increased in the presence of MWCNT (21). The bioavailability 73 of phenanthrene to Oryzias latipes was enhanced by MWCNT (22), and the 74 bioaccumulation of pyrene in earthworms was decreased by MWCNT and SWCNT 75 (23). 76
Page 4 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
It should be highlighted that a series of knowledge gaps arises when standard toxicity 77 tests are applied to assess NMs, including how to confirm the concentrations of 78 exposure and the characterization of the test media (8). Besides, some of the current 79 regulatory requirements for aquatic ecotoxicity tests for chemicals are difficult to be 80 accomplished when the same tests are used to assess NMs. For example, for the 81 evaluation of chemicals, it is often required to maintain at least 80% of the nominal test 82 concentrations during the exposure. In order to achieve this high percentage in the case 83 of NMs, the use of synthetic dispersive agents, sonication or solvents is necessary to 84 deal with the particularities of their colloidal chemistry. If the tests are carried out under 85 conditions that are far from the environment, responses with low ecotoxicological 86 relevance are obtained, that cannot be used in risk assessment studies. In addition, many 87 toxicity studies rely on the ability to quantify the interactions between NMs and 88 cells/organisms, including their uptake by cells. Many reports have shown that the 89 bioavailability of NMs depends on their size (24), shape (25) and surface coating (26, 90 27), sedimentation, aggregation and dissymmetry (28). For these reasons, in many 91 cases, to obtain information on environmental exposure some compromises should be 92 adopted. In this context, the measurement of NMs distribution in model estuarine 93 systems has been proposed (29) as a necessary first step towards the evaluation of their 94 effects on the environment. 95 The aim of this study was to investigate the toxicity of three carbon NMs suspensions 96 (fullerene-soot, MWCNT and graphene), aged under realistic conditions in microcosm 97 experiments simulating an estuary scenario. These carbon NMs were chosen from 98 among those with relevance in nanotechnology and also those that can be generated by 99 anthropogenic and natural sources. Estuaries were selected as the case study because 100 higher pollution rates occur through runoff together with re-suspension phenomena, 101 high evaporation rates, and intermediate salinity. Microcosms suspensions were 102 prepared by stirring, in the presence of organic material, water oxygenation, salinity and 103 temperature, which are typical in a Mediterranean estuary. In addition, day/night 104 insolation periods were reproduced. 105 Finally, their potential to modulate the toxicity of organic co-contaminants 106 (nonylphenol, triclosan, glyphosate, diuron and malathion), commonly detected in the 107 aquatic environment (30-32), was assessed. 108 Two aquatic toxicity tests, either based on the bioluminescence inhibition of the marine 109 bacteria V. fischeri and on the mobility inhibition of the microcrustacean Daphnia 110
Page 5 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
magna were conducted for individual NMs and mixtures of NMs and organic 111 contaminants. 112 The toxicity of mixtures was assessed by the isobologram method. Isobolograms are 113 highly visual and informative graphs where the composition of those mixtures 114 presenting the same toxicity (typically, but not exclusively, the 50% effective 115 concentration (EC50) are matched with a line that may be straight, concave or convex, 116 indicating respectively an additive behavior, antagonism or synergism. The isobologram 117 method was used to evaluate the concentrations producing an effect, in comparison to 118 those predicted by a simple additive approach. 119 120 Experimental section 121 Chemicals The standards used in this study were of the highest purity available. 122 Analytical standards of nonylphenol technical mixture (≤99.9%, reference 46018), 123 malathion (≤99%, reference PS86), diuron (≤99.4%, reference 45463) and glyphosate 124 (≤99%, reference PS1051) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Steinheim, Germany). 125 Triclosan (≤99.5%, reference C 17803000) was purchased from Dr. Ehrenstorfer 126 (Ausberg, Germany). Mother solutions of nonylphenol, triclosan, malathion, diuron and 127 glyphosate were prepared at 5, 10, 0.1, 40, and 1,000 mg/l, respectively, with no 128 utilisation of organic solvent, in D. magna test medium for D. magna immobilization 129 assays and in 2% NaCl aqueous solution for V. fischeri bioluminescence inhibition 130 assays. NaCl was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (reference S9888); water and toluene, 131 HPLC grade, were obtained from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). 132 According to the supplier, the initial characteristics of NMs were as follows: Fullerene 133 soot (76% of C60 fullerene, 22% of C70 fullerene and 2% of higher-order fullerenes) was 134 produced by the Kratschmer-Huffman arc method, and MWCNT (average outer 135 diameter of 12 nm and lengths compressed between 2.5 and 20 µm; carbon basis purity 136 >98%) were produced by the chemical vapor deposition method and were purchased 137 from Sigma-Aldrich. Graphene nano-powder consisting of 1.5–10 µm particles (4.5 µm 138 mean size) composed of 12 nm graphene flakes (equivalent to 30–50 graphene layers) 139 was supplied by Graphene Supermarket (Reading, MA, USA). 140 141 Preparation and characterization of carbon NMs suspensions Artificial estuary 142 water (AEW) were prepared by combining 50% of artificial seawater (ASW) and 50% 143 of artificial freshwater (AFW). ASW was produced according to a recipe described 144
Page 6 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
before (33). The pH was adjusted to 8.2, and the organic matter was simulated by 145 adding 10 mg/l of humic acid of technical grade from Sigma-Aldrich (reference 53680). 146 The AFW was prepared according to the description of Lipschitz and Michel (34). The 147 compositions of AEW is summarized in Table S1 of the Supporting information 148 section. Standard suspensions in AEW were prepared as 100 mg/l of each NM by long-149 term stirring during 40 days in loosely-capped glass bottles to assure the oxygenation of 150 the suspension and light exposure as occurs in the natural environment. In addition, 151 stirring was controlled to maintain at least 8 mg/l of dissolved oxygen, illumination was 152 simulated for day and night periods, and the temperature was set at 18±0.2 ºC. 153 Standard suspensions were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and 154 nano-tracking analysis (NTA). SEM experiments were carried out with a NOVA 155 NanoSEM 230 (FEI) employing a secondary-electron detector (Everhart-Thornley 156 detector) and a back-scattered electron detector. A drop of suspension was placed onto a 157 silica surface and left undisturbed overnight until dryness for the purpose of 158 characterization. Micrographs were acquired with magnification factors from 1,000 to 159 250,000×, using an acceleration voltage of 5 kV and probe currents from 56 to 450 pA. 160 NTA analysis of each suspension was performed in static mode with a NanoSight 161 instrument model LM10-HS (NanoSight, UK). A pre-scan was carried out in order to 162 adjust the camera level and data threshold with respect to the characteristics of each 163 sample prior to sample characterization. In order to track a significant number of 164 nanoparticles, measurements were carried out in quintuplicate with recordings of 165 between 60 and 90 seconds duration. 3000-6000 nanoparticles were recorded per run. 166 The five population distributions were normalized and averaged in order to obtain the 167 final plot. 168 169 Acute toxicity assays Two standard ecotoxicity bioassays, the immobilization of D. 170 magna and the bioluminescence inhibition of V. fischeri, were performed to assess the 171 individual toxicity of selected pollutants in the previously described conditions. Due to 172 the short times of exposure (48 h for D. magna and 30 min for the test with bacteria V. 173 fischeri), and in order to avoid the stress of test organisms during the time of exposure, 174 assay media were not changed during the whole assay. 175 D. magna static acute 24–48 h toxicity assays were conducted according to the standard 176 methods OECD Guideline 202 and ISO 6341. Very briefly, the test is conducted using 177 neonates, hatched from eggs at 20–22 °C under continuous illumination of 6000 lux 178
Page 7 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
during 3 days. For each test, a bench of dilutions is prepared and around 10 neonates are 179 exposed to each dilution in darkness at 20 °C. For each test a control solution was 180 conducted and measured together. After 24 h and 48 h of exposure, the number of 181 immobilized organisms was determined. Immobility at 24 h and 48 h was the bioassay 182 endpoint, assumed to be equivalent to mortality. 183 The test based on the bioluminescence inhibition of the marine bacteria V. fischeri 184 followed ISO protocol 11348. The tests were carried out with all dilutions and reagents 185 tempered at 15 °C. For the good performance of the tests, the osmolality was adjusted to 186 2 % of saline in each solution or sample. The bacterial reagent was reconstituted just 187 before the analysis and the pre-incubation times following standard protocols. In all 188 measures, the percentage of inhibition (% I) was determined by comparing the response 189 given by a blank ASW with the adjusted osmolality. Bioluminescence measurements 190 were performed after 15 and 30 min of incubation at 15 ºC using the luminometer 191 Microtox Toxicity Model 500 Analyzer (SDIX). All measurements were carried out in 192 triplicate. 193 The toxicity results were used to fit the inhibition curves for each substance and NMs 194 using both tests. The 50% effective concentrations (EC50), the toxicity units (TU), the 195 Lowest Observed Effect Concentration (LOEC) and the No-Observed-Effect 196 Concentration (NOEC) values were determined in each case. For D. magna the LOEC 197 was defined as the lowest toxicant concentration that causes inhibition after 48 hours 198 exposure, whereas for V. fischeri the LOEC was defined as the lowest toxicant 199 concentration that causes bioluminescence inhibition after 30 minutes of exposure. 200 NOEC was defined for the D. magna test as the highest toxicant concentration that is 201 observed not to cause any effect after 48 hours exposure, and for V. fischeri NOEC was 202 defined as the highest toxicant concentration that is observed not to cause any effect 203 after 30 minutes exposure. TU was defined as in Eq. 1. 204
(1) 205
Isobolograms method The synergistic/antagonistic effects of binary mixtures 206 composed by NMs suspension and a xenobiotic were assessed. Isobolograms (35) are 207 constructed on a coordinate system composed of the individual toxicant doses of the 208 two components of the mixture (36). Briefly, given two toxicants, their doses A and B, 209 which produce a determined effect, are marked in the corresponding axis of the 210 isobologram. Then, all those binary mixtures of composition a+b, which experimentally 211
50EC
1 100TU ×=
Page 8 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
produce the same toxic effect as A alone or B alone, are then plotted. γ is defined as in 212 Eq. 2: 213
(2) 214
In those systems where γ=1 the two toxicants follow a simple additive behavior and the 215 isobologram represents a straight line, while in those cases where γ>1 or γ<1 the 216 isobologram is parabolic, and antagonism or synergism is observed, respectively. 217 A and B can be calculated from Eq. 3, which is directly obtained from the tetra-218 parametric equation that describes the toxicity curves of individual toxicants. 219
(3) 220
ECx is the concentration which produces an inhibition percentage x, T (“top”) and B 221 (“bottom”) are the maximum and minimum values respectively at which the toxicity 222 curve asymptotically approaches (typically 100% and 0%, respectively) and H is the 223 slope of the linear section of the sigmoid. 224
Liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry analyses The concentration 225 of fullerene in water suspension was analyzed by liquid chromatography coupled to 226 high–resolution mass spectrometry (LC–HRMS). Fullerenes’ separation was achieved 227 by non-aqueous LC, using the Acquity UPLC System (Waters, Milford, MA, USA), 228 equipped with a Buckyprep (150×2.0 mm, particle size 5 µm) analytical column from 229 Nacalai Tesque (Kyoto, Japan) and using toluene (0.400 ml/min) as mobile phase. The 230 LC system was coupled with an APPI source to a Q-Exactive (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 231 San Jose, CA, USA) hybrid quadrupole–Orbitrap mass spectrometer. The acquisition 232 was performed in full scan (m/z 600–1200) with a resolution of 35,000 full width at 233 maximum height (fwhm) and in negative mode. 234
The sedimentation of fullerene aggregates in D. magna tests was assessed. AEW 235 suspensions of fullerene soot were diluted in D. magna medium to 6.4 mg/l and 9.4 236 mg/l in triplicate. Aliquots of 1 ml of suspension were subtracted after 24 h and 48 h. 237 The aliquots were placed in capped 5 ml glass vials together with 1 ml of toluene and a 238 liquid-liquid extraction (LLE) was performed. The bioaccumulation of fullerene soot in 239 D. magna organisms was also assessed at 6.4 mg/l and 9.4 mg/l. Six daphnids were 240 subtracted from each concentration after 24 h and 48 h. Half of the daphnids were 241

rinsed with ultrapure water according to the protocol of Tervonen et al. (37), while the 242 other half were not rinsed in order to analyze the aggregates attached to their dermis and 243 antennae. Daphnids were homogenized by ultrasounds for 10 minutes in 1 mL of 244 NaCl(aq) 2 and were then extracted using 1 ml of toluene by LLE. 245
246
Results and discussion 247 Characterization of aqueous suspensions As can be seen in SEM micrographs (Figure 248 1), fullerene aggregates ranged from 40 nm to 600 nm and micron-sized quasi-spherical 249 supra-aggregates, often with humic acids (Figure 1a and 1b). The formation of round-250 shape aggregates of <100 nm produced by intensive stirring was also confirmed (Figure 251 1c). This type of aggregates has been observed to be less toxic than those sharp-edged 252 aggregates that are obtained by sonication. 253 NTA analyses also confirmed a poly-disperse size distribution of fullerene aggregates 254 (see Figure 2) with nano-sized aggregates (relative maxima at 63 nm and 86 nm) and 255 other clusters with hydrodynamic diameters up to several hundreds of nanometers 256 (maximum peaks at 175 nm, ~250 nm and ~350 nm). NTA analyses were unable to 257 assess the distribution of the largest aggregates observed by SEM. 258 With regards to carbon nanotubes, they tangled, creating dissymmetrical aggregates 259 with variable sizes, from tens to hundreds of nanometers (Figure 1d) up to several 260 micrometers (Figure 1e). The smallest aggregates were composed of only a few 261 nanotubes and eventually discrete nanotubes could be distinguished (Figure 1f), in a 262 similar manner to previous works, because of the stabilizing effect of organic matter 263 (38). As can be seen in the NTA graphic (Figure 2), a wide distribution centered at 170 264 nm was found. MWCNTs surfaces showed some irregularities and their outer diameter 265 was larger than expected from the provider information. Because of the long aging 266 period of MWCNT, oxidation was likely to happen to some extent, increasing their 267 stability in water and their ability to absorb other dissolved molecules because of an 268 enhancement of π–π and n–π electron donor–acceptor interactions (39-41). 269 Finally, regarding the graphene suspension, multiple aggregates and supra-aggregates of 270 several micrometers (figure 1g) co-occurred with some few nano-sized quasi-spherical 271 aggregates (Figure 1h). Differently than in the two previous suspensions, the aggregates 272 presented sharp edges (see figure 1i). The size distribution profile was a symmetrical 273
Page 10 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
function centered at 300 nm (Figure 2), which is the largest maximum of the three 274 studied suspensions. 275 The toxicity of NMs will be directly linked to environmental conditions and how these 276 conditions may transform them, changing their aggregation states and bioavailability, as 277 well as their interaction with organic materials and other dissolved species. 278 279 Toxicity of NMs suspended in artificial estuary water In Tables 1 and 2, the toxicity 280 values and parameters for the V. fischeri and D. magna inhibition curves fitted for the 281 different compounds are summarized. The inhibition curves of NMs suspensions are 282 presented in Figure S1 of the Supporting Information. 283 According to the European Commission Directive 93/67/EEC (42), fullerene soot 284 presented moderate toxicity vs. V. fischeri, with an EC50 value of 26±2.2 mg/l after 30 285 minutes of incubation, while MWCNTs and graphene were not toxic for this organism. 286 D. magna was more sensitive to carbon NMs with toxicity as follows: fullerene soot > 287 MWCNT > graphene (EC50 values of 11±1.1, 14±0.3 and 20±0.5 mg/l, respectively). 288 This ranking can be related to the aggregates size distribution in the suspensions. Being 289 the most toxic ones those with the highest proportion of small aggregates, as expected 290 (43). While, other parameters such as their morphology can also influence their final 291 toxicity. In this case, the influence on the final toxicity of size was predominant over the 292 shape (SEM micrographs showed that graphene aggregates were a sharp-edged while, 293 on the contrary, fullerene soot aggregates were round-shaped). 294 In comparison to previous studies, MWCNT suspensions prepared in AEW were 295 slightly less toxic than suspensions obtained by simple mechanical stirring (44) and 296 significantly less toxic than suspensions obtained by solvent transfer or ultrasounds 297 (45). 298 On the other hand, different studies have reported toxicity data of pure fullerenes. For 299 example, Oberdörster et al. (46), reported that C60 fullerene did not show toxicity to D. 300 magna at concentrations up to 35 mg/l after 48 hours of exposure. In another study, Zhu 301 et al. (44) reported an EC50 of 9.344 mg/l after 21 days of exposure. The differences 302 with the present study can be attributed to the characteristics of the NM (fullerene soot 303 instead of pristine fullerene) and to the different mediums of dispersion (AEW instead 304 of ultrapure water), which results in different types of aggregates. It should be pointed 305 out that this study reports the first data informing on the ecotoxicity of the fullerene soot 306
Page 11 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
(which is the industrially produced material by the Krätschmer-Huffman synthesis) 307 instead of using high-purity fullerenes. 308 Finally, graphene showed an EC50 for D. magna of 20±0.5 mg/l, with a lower toxicity 309 than pristine graphene monolayer flakes, suspended in ASW by solvent transfer and 310 after filtration (47). 311 All these results indicate that the aging of carbon NMs aggregates in aerobic conditions, 312 change their toxicity increasing it, as it is the case of fullerenes, or decreasing it, as it is 313 the case of MWCNT and graphene. 314 Precipitation, resuspension and uptake of fullerene soot aggregates Given the 315 duration of the assays with D. magna (48 hours), the potential bioaccumulation by these 316 organisms (37) and sedimentation rates during the test, the concentration of suspended 317 fullerenes was quantified by LC-HRMS. The initial nominal concentration of fullerene 318 soot (6.4 mg/l) was decreased to 0.7 and 0.6 ng/l, after 24 and 48 hours, respectively. 319 Nevertheless, when daphnids were in the test medium, the concentrations of fullerenes 320 were higher because bottom agitation by organisms. When 10 organisms were exposed 321 to initial nominal concentrations of 6.4 mg/l the concentration of fullerenes in test 322 media was 280 and 112 µg/l after 48 and 24 hours, respectively. MWCNTs and 323 graphene are expected to present a similar behavior but, unfortunately, no accurate 324 quantitative analytical methods are available. 325 In these experiments the uptake and adsorption of carbon NMs by D. magna (Table S2 326 of the Supporting Information section) was shown. In previous studies, large amounts of 327 carbon NMs were adsorbed by the daphnids (antennae and body surface) resulting in an 328 abnormal swimming behavior, and, also, aggregates were immobilized in the gut tract 329 (37). In this study, the uptake of fullerenes was quantified. In order to distinguish the 330 external adsorption and the uptake, the concentrations by LC-MS analysis in washed 331 individuals were compared with the concentrations found in daphnids which were 332 externally covered by fullerenes. As can be seen in Table S2 of the Supporting 333 Information the uptake was about 47 µg/g. 334 335 Toxicity of binary mixtures to Vibrio fischeri The bioluminescence inhibition of V. 336 fischeri by exposure to binary mixtures of fullerene soot and nonylphenol, triclosan, 337 malathion and glyphosate was studied. Diuron was excluded from these experiments 338 because this compound was not toxic to V. fischeri. 339
Page 12 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
In Table S3 of the Supporting Information the concentrations of binary mixtures, the 340 inhibition percentage and the subsequent γ values are reported. As can be seen, γ was 341 always higher than 1, indicating antagonism. γ values for the mixtures of fullerene soot 342 and xenobiotics varied between 1.9 and 4.0, 2.5 and 16, 1.6 and 4.5 and from 1.3 and 343 3.4 for the mixtures of nonylphenol, triclosan, malathion and glyphosate, respectively. 344 In Figure 3, the isobolograms are presented. The straight lines correspond to an additive 345 model and the curves correspond to the real behavior, which also indicates antagonism 346 in all of the cases. 347 These results can be related to the sorptive properties of the aggregates of fullerene soot. 348 The relatively high hydrophobic substances were immobilized by the carbon clusters. 349 At low concentrations of organic contaminant, the toxic effect was similar to the toxic 350 effect that would be expected by the nanomaterial alone. This indicates the complete 351 adsorption of biocides by fullerene aggregates. By progressively increasing the 352 concentration of the biocides, an excess of biocides molecules in the media was 353 bioavailable therefore toxicity increased, but less than predicted by a simply additive 354 approach. 355 The concentration of free xenobiotic in dilution was experimentally proved. Binary 356 mixtures containing fullerene soot and organic contaminant were prepared in AEW at 357 different concentration ratios. These mixtures were mixed by mechanical agitation for 358 30 minutes. Then, fullerene soot aggregates were extracted by filtration using 0.45 µm 359 nylon fiber filters (48). The dissolved phase was analyzed by LC-HRMS. As can be 360 seen in Figure S2, the concentration of free diuron was lower in binary mixtures 361 containing a high amount of fullerene soot, proving its role as sorbent material. 362 Additional toxicity tests were prepared at concentrations, which would result in 363 inhibition percentages of 15, 20, 30 and 35% according to a simple additive approach. 364 As can be seen in Table S4, antagonisms were obtained again, as expected. The average 365 γ values (̅) of triclosan (γ =3.02), malathion (γ =2.33) and glyphosate (̅=1.68) tended 366 to increase together with their respective octanol-water coefficients, KOW (5.75×10 5 367
(49), 229 (49) and 3.98×10 -4 (49), respectively). Anther factor that can also support this 368 trend is the presence of aromatic rings in the molecule and the π- π interactions between 369 carbon nanomaterials and non-polar organic contaminants. Nonylphenol’s KOW/γ ratio 370 (~6.31×10 3 /1.95 (49)) distorts this relationship: because of its role as a tensoactive 371 substance allowing production of micelles and changing the state of aggregation of 372
Page 13 of 24
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
fullerene aggregates. Hence, the antagonistic relationship nonylphenol-fullerene soot 373 cannot be explained by a simple surface sorption processes. 374 375 Toxicity of binary mixtures to Daphnia magna Binary mixtures composed by 376 fullerene soot and nonylphenol, triclosan, malathion, diuron and glyphosate were 377 studied. As can be seen in the isobolograms presented in Figure 4, antagonism was the 378 most common effect as did occur with V. fischeri. 379 γ values were higher than 1.0 in most of the cases, as indicated in Table S5 and Figure 380 S3 of the Supporting Information, indicating antagonistic relationships. 381 A different behavior was observed for malathion-fullerene soot mixtures. In this case, 382 synergism was observed during a significant section of the isobologram, at those 383 concentrations where the molar ratio malathion/fullerene soot was higher. This behavior 384 had not been observed in V. fischeri experiments and can be related to daphnid 385 filtration: Daphnids actively accumulated fullerene aggregates doped with malathion 386 molecules. In those binary mixtures where fullerene soot concentrations were high 387 enough, malathion was efficiently immobilized, whereas in those binary mixtures where 388 fullerene aggregates surface was saturated, loosely attached malathion molecules were 389 released inside the microcrustacean organisms. In Figure S2 of the Supporting 390 Information, the weak attachment of malathion molecules onto the surface of the 391 aggregates can be shown. The concentration of free malathion is maintained relatively 392 constant in the presence of fullerene soot, in contrast to what happened with diuron. 393 Therefore, it can be concluded that the affinity of malathion to fullerene soot was 394 moderate due to the lack of aromatic rings. Further, the affinity of malathion to D. 395 magna is expected to be significant according to the bioconcentration factor of this 396 pesticide to shrimps, logBCFmalathion=2.94–2.98 (50), which favors its partition from the 397 fullerene soot to the organism. 398 The change in the bioavailability of contaminants, because of the vector function of 399 carbon NM’s aggregates, is referred to as the Trojan horse effect. The unexpected 400 release of malathion from fullerene aggregates, accumulated inner of D. magna, is an 401 example. 402 The Trojan horse effect observed in the case of malathion is likely to be found in 403 experiments with other organic pollutants with intermediate affinity to carbon NMs. 404 The most hydrophilic compounds will be less likely to be immobilized by fullerene 405 aggregates (or any other carbon nanomaterial) and will remain in water solution. 406
Page 14 of 24

Environmental Science & Technology
However, the most non-polar compounds presenting aromatic rings, such as diuron, will 407 be readily immobilized and their toxic activity will decrease dramatically (see Figure 408 4d). Finally, the intermediate compounds may use carbon nanomaterials aggregates as 409 vectors for being introduced and released inside filter organisms. With these results, we 410 have demonstrated here the high dependency of environmental behavior in toxicity of 411 NMs and how the presence of NMs can modulate the toxicological profile of mixtures 412 with xenobiotics. 413 414 Acknowledgements 415 This work was supported by the Spanish Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness 416 through the projects Nano-Trojan (CTM-2011-24051) and SCARCE (Consolider-417 Ingenio 2010 CSD2009- 00065) and by the Generalitat de Catalunya (Consolidated 418 Research Groups “2014 SGR 418 - Water and Soil Quality Unit” and 2014 SGR 291 - 419 ICRA). The authors would like to express their deepest gratitude to the Nanotechnology 420 Platform from the Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia (IBER), because of their 421 kind assistance on the SEM characterization, and to Roser Chaler and Dori Fanjul, 422 because of their technical support during the LC-HRMS analyses 423 424 Additional information 425 The authors declare no competing financial interests. referenceMentions.context: Introduction 44 The production and use of the different groups of nanomaterials (NMs) is expected to 45 increase during the coming years (1).

Carbon NMs such as fullerenes, multiwall carbon 46 nanotubes (MWCNTs) and graphene nanoflakes are currently applied in electronics (2, 47 3), as potential drug carriers (4), in analytical chemistry (5), and are the basis of new 48 materials (6).

Carbon NMs such as fullerenes, multiwall carbon 46 nanotubes (MWCNTs) and graphene nanoflakes are currently applied in electronics (2, 47 3), as potential drug carriers (4), in analytical chemistry (5), and are the basis of new 48 materials (6).

Carbon NMs such as fullerenes, multiwall carbon 46 nanotubes (MWCNTs) and graphene nanoflakes are currently applied in electronics (2, 47 3), as potential drug carriers (4), in analytical chemistry (5), and are the basis of new 48 materials (6).
Moreover, carbon NMs are also emitted from combustion sources (7).

49 However, the same physical properties based on their large surface-to-volume ratio that 50 have made the nanotechnological success are also the basis of their potential risk for the 51 environment and living organisms (8, 9).

53 The fate, behavior and potential risks of the increasing presence of NMs in the 54 environment, continue to be poorly understood (11).

The bioavailability 73 of phenanthrene to Oryzias latipes was enhanced by MWCNT (22), and the 74 bioaccumulation of pyrene in earthworms was decreased by MWCNT and SWCNT 75 (23).

It should be highlighted that a series of knowledge gaps arises when standard toxicity 77 tests are applied to assess NMs, including how to confirm the concentrations of 78 exposure and the characterization of the test media (8).
Many reports have shown that the 89 bioavailability of NMs depends on their size (24), shape (25) and surface coating (26, 90 27), sedimentation, aggregation and dissymmetry (28).
In this context, the measurement of NMs distribution in model estuarine 93 systems has been proposed (29) as a necessary first step towards the evaluation of their 94 effects on the environment.

metadata.abstractText: 19 At present, there is a lack of understanding on the combined ecotoxicity of carbon20 based nanomaterials and co-contaminants. In this paper, we report on the toxicity of 21 three carbon nanomaterials (fullerene-soot, multiwall carbon nanotubes and 22 graphene). 23 Two standardized toxicity bioassays, the immobilization of the invertebrate Daphnia 24 magna and the bioluminescence inhibition of the marine bacteria Vibrio fischeri, have 25 been used. Synergistic and antagonistic effects of binary mixtures composed of 26 fullerene soot and organic co-contaminants as malathion, glyphosate, diuron, triclosan, 27 and nonylphenol were assessed. The isobologram method was used to evaluate the 28 concentrations producing an effect, in comparison to those effects expected by a simple 29 additive approach. In this study, antagonism was the predominant effect. However, 30 synergism was also observed as in the case of D. magna exposed to mixtures of 31 malathion and fullerene soot. D. magna was shown to be the most sensitive assay when 32 carbon nanomaterials were present. Toxicity to D. magna was as follows: fullerene soot 33 > multi-wall carbon nanotubes > graphene. These results were proportional to the size 34 of aggregates, smaller aggregates being the most toxic. The vector function of 35 nanomaterials aggregates and the unexpected release inside living organisms was 36 proved for malathion. 37 These results highlight new insights on the risks associated with the release of carbon 38 nanomaterials into the environment. 39 40
